	<choices>
		<choice section="493">Visit the market</choice>

book2.168.xml:

<section name="169">
	You approach the captain of a two-masted merchantman. He
	looks you up and down and rubs his jaw thoughtfully. ‘Where
	are you bound?’ he asks. You soon discover that passage to
	Dweomer or Marlock City will cost you 10 Shards, while

	pay the fare and set sail at once, or give up and review your

	<choices>

You pass rumbling ox-drawn carts and mule trains laden with grain and cloth. Much trade passes up and down this road.

You can leave possessions and money here to save having to carry them around with you. Write in the box anything you’re leaving here. Each time you return, :

Your possessions are safe A thief; all the money you left here has gone A gang of burglars; lose all possessions you left here

You can also rest at your town house for as long as you wish. If injured, restore your Stamina to its normal unwounded score.

When you’ve finished at your town house, .

<section name="172">

If you are an initiate it costs only 5 Shards to propitiate the twin gods of the sea. A non-initiate must pay 30 Shards.

Cross off the money and write Safety from Storms in the Blessings box on your Adventure Sheet. The blessing works by allowing you to ignore any one storm at sea. When you use the blessing, cross it off your Adventure Sheet.

You can have only one Safety from Storms blessing at any time. Once it is used up, you can return to any branch of the temple of Alvir and Valmir to buy a new one.

When you are finished here, .

To renounce the worship of Alvir and Valmir, you must pay 30 Shards in compensation to the priesthood. The priests advise you not to put to sea for a while after renouncing your initiate’s vows - ‘in case the gods are angered by your faithlessness.’

Do you want to reconsider? If you are determined to renounce your faith, pay the 30 Shards and delete Alvir and Valmir from the God box on your Adventure Sheet. When you have finished here, .
book2.18.xml:
You tell the high priest that you wish to renounce the worship of Nagil. He shows you your reflection in a mirror, then shatters it against the altar. When you ask if you must pay compensation to the temple, he shakes his head. ‘It is you who loses, not we.’

Do you want to reconsider? If you are determined to renounce your faith, delete Nagil from the God box on your Adventure Sheet. You must lose any outstanding resurrection arrangements. Also lose the title Chosen One of Nagil if you have it. When you have finished here, .
book2.180.xml:
‘Surround yourself with the symbols of luck,’ you overhear a priestess saying to a supplicant. ‘Then the threefold goddess shall smile on you.’

If you have a rabbit’s foot charm, . If not, .
book2.181.xml:
If you are an initiate it costs only 10 Shards to purchase Tyrnai’s blessing. A non-initiate must pay 25 Shards.

Cross off the money and write COMBAT in the Blessings box on your Adventure Sheet. The blessing works by allowing you to try again when you make a failed COMBAT roll. It is only good for one reroll. When you use the blessing, cross it off your Adventure Sheet.

You can have only one COMBAT blessing at any one time. Once it is used up, you can return to any branch of the temple of Tyrnai to buy a new one.

When you are finished here, .
book2.182.xml:
You show the lepers you are not afraid to stay amongst them. They are grateful for your help in various chores that they find difficult. Gain 1 point of SANCTITY.

The next day you set out on your way once more. As you go, one of the lepers warns you: ‘In that direction lies the village of the Bald Ones. Don’t trust them - they’d soon as slit your throat as look at you. The path by their village leads to the heart of the woods.’

.
book2.183.xml:
The interior of the tomb is lighted by a greyish glow. A corpse in ancient knightly regalia lies on a stone slab. Awakened by your approach, it sits up. Cobwebs veil its eye sockets and its skin looks like the bark of a dead tree. It extends an accusing finger.

‘For disturbing my slumber I should strike you dead where you stand,’ it intones in a gravid voice. ‘But there is a way for you to earn a reprieve.’

Turn and run Wait to hear what it suggests
book2.184.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="184">
	It was no ordinary wolf, but some sort of enchanted beast with
	the power of regeneration. Under your very eyes the splintered
	bones are knitting together, the blood pouring back through its
	wounds, the torn pelt becoming whole again. If you tarry here
	too long you will have to fight it all over again.
	<choices>
		<choice section="253">Climb the stairs</choice>
		<choice section="22">Leave the tower</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.185.xml:
A sprawling single-storey cottage squats incongrously amid the thick black tree trunks. In front is a well from which a man in a homespun tunic is raising water. Hearing you approach, he turns and greets you cautiously.

‘I am Knocklar the hermit,’ he says. ‘I don’t get all that many visitors here in the Forest of the Forsaken. Are you lost?’

If you have a severed head, . If not, .
book2.186.xml:
He tells a story of a woodcutter who fell asleep one afternoon and awoke to find it was dark. Having lost his way he was very frightened, but then he saw smoke over the treetops. Going on, he reached a camp where slim young gypsy maidens were dancing around a fire. With smiles and merry laughs, they invited the woodcutter to join them. Now it so happened that the woodcutter’s grandmother had been a gypsy, and she’d taught him the traditional greeting that he now called out: ‘Dza devlesa!’ which is to say, ‘May the gods be with you!’ No sooner had the maidens heard this than they all collapsed like matchwood and, creeping closer, the woodcutter saw that there were just piles of mouldering bones in the clearing, and not living people at all.

‘...So you know what he did?’ concludes the storyteller. ‘He climbed an oak tree and stayed there shivering until dawn, because he knew that no ghost can follow you up an oak tree.’

The day is wearing on, and it is time you were on your way. Get the codeword Bones and .

The Three Fortunes are the goddesses of fate, who weave the tapestry of all men’s lives. A placard outside the temple declares: ‘Join the temple and see your luck change overnight!’ Inside, a vast wall painting shows a three-faced deity with six limbs hurling down nuggets of gold from a palace among the clouds.

Do you have the title Beloved of the Three Fortunes? If so, . If not, .

Your other option is to set out across the open countryside - there are no roads to speak of in this wild, unforgiving landscape.

	brightly painted timber frames. The burghers of the town are

	that we pay tax to the Sokarans, and the Sokarans that we pay

Owning a ship has two advantages. First, it makes it much easier to travel around. Second, it allows you to get rich by trading goods in bulk.

Goods are transported in Cargo Units. (A Cargo Unit weighs several tonnes - much more than one person could carry!) The more expensive your ship, the greater its carrying capacity. More expensive ships are also more seaworthy.

Choose a ship from the types listed here.

Record your ship in the box provided on the Ship’s Manifest. You get to choose the ship’s name. The crew quality is average unless you hire on better sailors. Each time you arrive at a new destination, change the entry in the Docked column to the ship’s current location. (So, if you aren’t going to set sail immediately, note that the ship is docked at Ringhorn.)

Hire on better crew Leave the city Visit the warehouses Return to the city centre

book2.206.xml:
Suppressing a shudder, you put the glittering into the undead creature’s hands. It gives a dry hiss of pleasure.

‘Now I know my treasure is safe, I shall sleep soundly,’ it says.

Closing its dead grey fingers tight around the precious key, it lies back on its slab and become inert once more.

Attack it Quietly search the crypt Leave at once
book2.207.xml:
With a growl, it leaps forward, fangs bared hungrily. You must fight.

Because the faery wolf is chained to the wall, you can flee from combat at any time, but you will take a final wound of 1-6 Stamina points (roll one die for how many) as you run away from the creature.

Fight and kill the wolf Flee from the tower
book2.208.xml:
You are caught in a web whose strands are as thick as a trawler’s net.

Feeling the warning of your sixth sense, you look up into the branches in time to see a globular shape with many long hairy legs dropping silently out of the darkness.

Because you are tangled in the web, you cannot run away from this fight.

A sign hanging outside the inn proclaims: Civilization stops here! ‘Surely you risk offending travellers coming from the other direction,’ you say to the innkeeper, a friendly man named Troilus.

With a beaming smile, he leads you to the other side of the sign. The same words are written there. ‘I flatter everyone, offend no one. It is a good philosophy of life.’

Troilus charges 1 Shard a day for board and lodging. Each day you spend here, you can recover 1 Stamina point if injured, up to the limit of your normal unwounded Stamina score. When you are ready to leave, .

book2.232.xml:
Ringhorn market consists of hundreds of stalls crowded into a cobbled square under the walls of the Sheriff’s citadel. This is where you can buy or sell personal items. Items with no purchase price are not available locally.

For bulk trade goods you need to visit the warehouses at the waterfront. When you’re through here, .
book2.233.xml:
There are two advantages to owning a ship. First, it makes it much easier to travel around. Second, it allows you to get rich by trading goods in bulk. Goods are transported in Cargo Units. (A Cargo Unit weighs several tonnes - much more than one person could carry!) The more expensive your ship, the greater its carrying capacity. More expensive ships are also more seaworthy.

Choose a ship from the types listed here.

Record your ship in the box provided on the Ship’s Manifest. You get to choose the ship’s name. The crew quality is average unless you hire on better sailors. Each time you arrive at a new destination, change the entry in the Docked column to the ship’s current location. (So, if you aren’t going to sail straightaway, note that the ship is docked at Wishport.)

Hire on better crew Leave the city Visit the warehouses Return to the city centre

When you are finished here, .

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="248">
	Mischievous elfin fingers delve into your haversack when you aren’t looking. You must lose 1-6 possessions (<random dice="1" var="x">roll a die</random> to see how many).
	<lose item="?" multiple="x">The items stolen</lose> are the ones listed first on your Adventure Sheet.
	<if codeword="Bosky">
		If you have the codeword Bosky, <goto section="300"/>.
	</if>
	If not, <goto section="93"/>.
</section>

book2.249.xml: The worshippers of the Three Fortunes admire you as a paragon of the faith. ‘You are an example to us all,’ says a bent-backed old prospector with a gold tooth. If you have a four-leafed clover, . If not, .
book2.25.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="25" image="25.jpg">
	The white turrets of Castle Ravayne rise above the treetops.
	From the topmost tower flutters the black lion banner of the
	Ravayne clan. This is the stronghold of Vanna, Baroness of
	Ravayne.
	<choices>
		<choice section="95">Enter the castle</choice>
		<choice section="118">Travel on further</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.250.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="250">
	The guards recognize you as a champion of the noble house of
	Ravayne. They salute as you go into the keep. <goto section="342"/>.
</section>
book2.251.xml:
You lash out, knocking the dwarf to the ground. As he sits cradling his head, you hurry over to the figure on horseback. As you lift the visor, a wisp of green smoke curls out and you hear a voice say: ‘I thank you, mortal, for my freedom.’

The smoke disperses on the breeze: the armour is empty.

Get the codewords Bosky and Baluster. You can also take and a , since the dwarf is in no fit state to stop you.

Continue along the path Turn back
book2.252.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="252">
	Your body is found floating face down under the boardwalk
	leading to the shipyards. If you have resurrection arranged,
	<resurrection>turn to the section noted</resurrection>
	on your Adventure Sheet. Otherwise your
	great adventuring career has come to a rather ignoble end.
</section>
book2.253.xml:
At the top of the staircase you come to a belfry filled with roosting vampire bats that hang like sacks of dun-coloured leather around a vast iron bell. A loathsome trickle of fleas and lice falls constantly from the bats’ fur.

If the box above is not ticked, tick it now and . If the box is already ticked, .
book2.254.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="254" boxes="1">
	<if ticks="0">
		If the box above is not ticked,
		<tick>tick it now</tick> and <goto section="580"/>.
	</if>
	If the box is already ticked, <goto section="604"/>.
</section>
book2.255.xml:
At the harbour of Ringhorn you can buy a ship - or put to sea, if you already have a ship docked at this location.

While you are here it is also possible to visit the warehouses lining the waterfront, where goods from afar are bought and sold in quantity.

Buy a ship Sell a ship Go aboard your ship Hire crew for your ship Pay for passage on a ship Visit the warehouses Return to the city centre
book2.256.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="256" dock="Wishport">
	You can get the following price for a second-hand ship:
	<market>
		<header header1="Type" header2="Sale price"/>
		<trade ship="barque" sell="210"/>
		<trade ship="brigantine" sell="400"/>
		<trade ship="galleon" sell="800"/>
	</market>
	Remember to cross the ship off the Ship’s Manifest if you go ahead with the sale. When you have finished your business here, <goto section="325"/>.
</section>
book2.257.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="257" tag="temple">
	The temple of Nagil here in Wheatfields is decorated with wall
	carvings showing sheafs of fresh corn. ‘Most think of Nagil as
	the death god,’ explains a priest, ‘but of course he is more than
	that. In nature, where can there be rebirth and growth without
	death?’
	<choices>
		<choice section="362">Become an initiate of Nagil</choice>
		<choice section="18">Renounce his worship</choice>
		<choice section="41">Make resurrection arrangements</choice>
		<choice section="71">Leave the temple</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.258.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="258">
	You can head south to Ringhorn, or north to Castle Ravayne
	and beyond.
	<choices>
		<choice section="2">Travel to Ringhorn</choice>
		<choice section="25">Travel to Castle Ravayne</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.259.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="259">
	Wind whistles across a wide expanse of heathland dotted with
	just a few scattered hamlets. To the north, half hidden in the
	murk of low cloud, looms the snow-peaked mountain range
	known as the Spine of Harkun.
	<choices>
		<choice section="305">Head east towards the Haunted Hills</choice>
		<choice section="282">Head north towards the mountains</choice>
		<choice section="236">Travel west</choice>
		<choice section="328">Travel south</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.26.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="26">
	You are on the road that follows the banks of the Rese River
	between Castle Ravayne and the port city of Ringhorn.
	<random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-5" section="558">Attacked by highwaymen</outcome>
		<outcome range="6-7" section="258">An uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-12" section="408">You meet a militia patrol</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.260.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="260">
	You are walking along the bank of the River Grimm - called
	the ‘River of Souls’ because it is said to carry ghost barges laden
	with the souls of the dead. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-6" section="548">Travellers from Sokara</outcome>
		<outcome range="7-8" section="130">An uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="9-12" section="573">River Wraiths</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.261.xml:
The ship manoeuvres out of the harbour and on to the open sea. ‘We’ll have no trouble on this voyage,’ announces the captain. ‘I took the precaution of buying a charm of protection from Fortuity College in Dweomer.’

Whether it is the power of the charm or simple good luck, the journey is indeed without mishap and a few days later you dock at Dweomer. Turn to 100 in Over the Blood-Dark Sea.
book2.262.xml:
The voyage from Metriciens to Marlock City takes only a few days. You are amazed that it passes without incident, until the captain tells you: ‘I pay a regular tribute to the Reavers. They don’t need to intercept my ship to get money out of me.’

Turn to 240 in The War-Torn Kingdom.
book2.263.xml:
The road follows the ridge of low hills extending out into the headland of Knucklebones Point.

for encounters:

Eerie things Uneventful journey Penniless adventurers
book2.264.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="264">
	The boat takes you upriver as far as Castle Ravayne, a journey of
	several days. You can disembark here or stay on board and travel
	further upriver.
	<choices>
		<choice section="25">Visit Castle Ravayne</choice>
		<choice section="281">Journey upriver</choice>
		<choice book="5" section="222">Disembark and go west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.265.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="265">
	You are on the road between Haggart’s Corner and the
	Monastery of Molhern.
	<choices>
		<choice section="150">Follow the road to Haggart’s Corner</choice>
		<choice section="94">Follow the road to the monastery</choice>
		<choice section="196">Venture south off the road</choice>
		<choice section="54">Strike out cross-country to the west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.266.xml:
You sail out of Wishport towards Marlock City. Only a few days out, the crew begins to succumb to fever. Soon the ship is drifting unmanned while most of the sailors lie groaning below deck. You catch the fever yourself and must permanently lose 1-3 Stamina points (roll one die and halve the result, rounding fractions up). If you have the blessing of Immunity to Disease/Poison you can ignore this. Remember that the blessing is then used up.

If you survive, eventually enough crewmen recover to sail the ship on to its destination. Turn to 240 in The War-Torn Kingdom.
book2.267.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="267">
	<!-- Test is for 'cutting' weapons. Should we include scimitars? -->
	<if weapon="*sword*|*axe*|*katana*|*scimitar*" using="t">
		If you are fighting with a sword, axe, katana or scimitar, <goto section="313"/>.
	</if>
	Otherwise <goto section="152"/>.
</section>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="268">
	You are on the headland that stretches out to Knucklebones
	Point.
	<choices>
		<choice section="291">Go south to the coast</choice>
		<choice section="48">Go west to Metriciens</choice>
		<choice section="217">Go east to Wishport</choice>
		<choice section="150">Go north to Haggart’s Corner</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.269.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="269">
	‘Welcome, dear friend,’ says the high priest in greeting. ‘I trust
	your fortune grows as quickly as your fame?’
	<choices>
		<choice section="220">Renounce the worship of Alvir and Valmir</choice>
		<choice section="243">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="2">Leave the temple</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.27.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="27" tag="temple">
	The Three Fortunes are the goddesses of fate, who weave the
	tapestry of all men’s lives. Their temple is a high-ceilinged
	edifice dimly illuminated by three altar candles.
	<choices>
		<choice section="225">Become an initiate of the Fortunes</choice>
		<choice section="24">Renounce their worship</choice>
		<choice section="271">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="217">Leave the temple</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.270.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="270">
	<if not="t" safeAddGod="Nagil">
		Becoming an initiate of Nagil is not possible if you are already an initiate of another temple.
	</if>
	<else>
		You are made to undergo various trials to test your worthiness. In the last test, you are sealed in a casket below the ground and made to confront your own fears. To pass the test you must
		<random dice="1" var="x">
			roll under your Rank on one die
		</random>.
		<set var="rank" value="rank" modifier="natural"/>
		<if var="x" lessthan="rank">
			If successful, <tick god="Nagil">write Nagil in the God box</tick> on your Adventure Sheet.
		</if>
	</else>
	Once you have finished here, <goto section="125"/>.
</section>
book2.271.xml:
If you are an initiate it costs only 20 Shards to purchase The Three Fortunes’ blessing. A non-initiate must pay 80 Shards.

Cross off the money and mark Luck in the Blessings box on your Adventure Sheet. The blessing works by allowing you to reroll any dice result once. (This does not have to be an ability roll. You could also use it to reroll an encounter result.) When you use the blessing, cross it off your Adventure Sheet.

You can have only one Luck blessing at any one time. Once it is used up, you can return to any branch of the temple of The Three Fortunes to buy a new one.

When you are finished here, .
book2.272.xml:
A gaunt woman accosts you in the nave of the temple and says: ‘If only I had such a collection of lucky charms as you’ve got there.’

If you decide to give her your four-leaf clover, silver horseshoe and rabbit’s foot charm, remember to cross them off your Adventure Sheet.

Give her the three items Keep them
book2.273.xml:
The guards are not convinced you are important enough to be admitted to the keep. ‘Has the baroness summoned you?’ they demand to know. ‘She is very busy.’

To convince them to let you in, you need to make a CHARISMA roll at a Difficulty of 10 .

Give up and walk off
book2.274.xml:
‘I’ll trounce you!’ sniggers the dwarf. ‘I mean, my master will.’

With that, he waddles off towards the pavillion. You are a little surprised that he isn’t going to stay and watch, since he seems so confident of the outcome.

Prepare to joust Turn back
book2.275.xml:
The corpse reaches out its skeletal hands, clutching your throat in a grip like a noose of ice. You struggle to break free, but your limbs have lost their strength. A ghastly chuckling pounds in your ears as the corpse feasts on your soul.

Attempt a SANCTITY roll at a Difficulty of 15 . If the roll is successful, your spirit is too pure for the fiend to ingest: you are hurled out of the tomb with the loss of 3-18 Stamina (roll three dice). If you survive, . If you fail the SANCTITY roll then even resurrection cannot save you from being utterly destroyed by the vampire knight.
book2.276.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="276">
	<!-- regal helm - treat as regular armour? or additional? -->
	The floor of the belfry is virtually covered with silver, gold and precious gems - all sprinkled with bat guano. Two items draw your gaze: a
	<weapon name="golden sword" bonus="2"/> and a
	<armour name="regal helm" bonus="3"/>. You can take these two items: record them as possessions on your Adventure Sheet. You can also try to gather some treasure before the vampire bats wake up.
	<choices>
		<choice section="322">Gather some treasure</choice>
		<choice section="22">Leave without further delay</choice>
	</choices>
</section>

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="276">
