book2.277.xml:
Its bite was venomous. If you were injured during the fight, lose an additional 1-6 Stamina points now. (Remember that if you have a blessing of the goddess Maka, you can use it to negate the effect of the poison.)

Assuming you survive, you search the spider’s den and find several corpses trussed up in web silk. Among the litter of mouldered bones, you find - treasure that the spider’s previous victims have no further use for. Note it on your Adventure Sheet and then .
book2.278.xml:
You can leave possessions and money here to save having to carry them around with you. Record in the box anything you wish to leave. Each time you return, :

Your possessions are safe A thief; all the money you left here has gone A gang of burglars; lose all possessions you left here A fire; your town house and all its contents have been destroyed

You can also rest at your town house for as long as you wish. If injured, restore your Stamina to its normal unwounded score. When you’ve finished at your town house, (and remember to erase the tick in the town house box there if it was destroyed by fire).
book2.279.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="279" dock="Wishport">
	You stride up the gangplank to find the crew dancing merrily to
	the tune of a flute. ‘Ah, shkipper, jush tryin’ to keep the crew
	trit ‘n’ fim,’ slurs the bo’sun as he hastily conceals a bottle of
	grog. You shake your head despairingly and go aft to your cabin.
	Maybe you should hire better crewmen?
	<choices>
		<choice section="217">Go back into town</choice>
		<choice section="325">Walk along the harbourfront</choice>
		<choice section="119" sail="t">Set sail</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.28.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="28" tag="temple">
	Here you can rest and recuperate if injured, join in the
	devotional rituals, or simply travel on to your next destination.
	<choices>
		<choice section="739">Recuperate from wounds</choice>
		<choice section="763">Study at the monastery</choice>
		<choice section="780">Pray to Molhern</choice>
		<choice section="126">Talk to the abbot</choice>
		<choice section="74">Travel on from here</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.280.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="280">
	You reach the road that connects Wheatfields with the port of
	Metriciens.
	<choices>
		<choice section="170">Follow the road</choice>
		<choice section="195">Go east over open country</choice>
		<choice section="98">Go west over open country</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.281.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="281">
	The boat slowly makes its way up the Rese River. On either
	bank lie scattered villages. Beyond, the fertile farmlands of
	Golnir stretch off to the horizon. After a few days you reach the
	village of Delpton, where you can disembark if you wish.
	<choices>
		<choice section="350">Continue upriver</choice>
		<choice section="6">Disembark here</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.282.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="282" image="282.jpg">
	High jagged peaks tumble up to the verge of heaven. Legend has
	it that this mountain range is the exposed backbone of the
	slaughtered god Harkun. As you clamber up a steep trail, you see
	a waterfall gushing from high above. Something metallic glitters
	in the rock face where the waterfall issues out.
	<choices>
		<choice section="508">Climb up for a closer look</choice>
		<choice section="533">Ignore it</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.283.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="283">
	Your options include hiring passage on a barge going south, at a
	cost of 3 Shards.
	<choices>
		<choice shards="3" book="1" section="240">Barge to Marlock City</choice>
		<choice section="260">Follow the riverbank south</choice>
		<choice section="214">Take the road west</choice>
		<choice section="99">Follow the River Grimm north</choice>
		<choice section="237">Follow the Rainbow River north</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.284.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="284" dock="Ringhorn">
	Asking around, you find the best prices that can be got for a
	second-hand vessel:
	<market>
		<header type="shipsale"/>
		<trade ship="barque" sell="210"/>
		<trade ship="brigantine" sell="400"/>
		<trade ship="galleon" sell="800"/>
	</market>
	If you go ahead with the sale, cross the ship off the Ship’s Manifest. <goto section="255"/>.
</section>
book2.285.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="285" dock="Metriciens">
	You browse through the warehouses in Metriciens. To turn a
	profit you must buy goods where they are cheap and sell them
	where they are in demand. Prices are quoted for single Cargo
	Units. Such large quantities can be transported only by ship.
	<market>
		<header type="cargo"/>
		<trade cargo="furs" buy="210" sell="189"/>
		<trade cargo="grain" buy="90" sell="81"/>
		<trade cargo="metals" buy="850" sell="765"/>
		<trade cargo="minerals" buy="650" sell="585"/>
		<trade cargo="spices" buy="800" sell="720"/>
		<trade cargo="textiles" buy="250" sell="225"/>
		<trade cargo="timber" buy="260" sell="234"/>
	</market>
	When you have completed your business here, <goto section="33"/>.
</section>
book2.286.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="286">
	You are leaving the town of Wheatfields.
	<choices>
		<choice section="328">Go north to the Endless Plains</choice>
		<choice section="327">Take the west road to Delpton</choice>
		<choice section="166">Take the road to Castle Ravayne</choice>
		<choice section="170">Take the road to Metriciens</choice>
		<choice section="309">Take the east road</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.287.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="287">
	You are on the road leading down to Metriciens on the coast.
	<choices>
		<choice section="48">Go south to Metriciens</choice>
		<choice section="193">Go north towards Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="78">Leave the road and head west</choice>
		<choice section="54">Leave the road and head east</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.288.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="288">
	You are on the road between Wishport and Haggart’s Corner.
	<choices>
		<choice section="217">Follow the road to Wishport</choice>
		<choice section="150">Go north to Haggart’s Corner</choice>
		<choice section="101">Go due south towards the coast</choice>
		<choice section="219">Go east into the Magwort Fens</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.289.xml:
The sides of the pit are funnelled to prevent you climbing out. After a while the brigands arrive, dropping a net to ensnare you. They strip you of all your possessions and cash (cross them off your Adventure Sheet). They are about to slit your throat when one of them thinks to ask if you have any money invested with the merchants’ guild. ‘Enough to pay a ransom of 150 Shards, say?’

If you can pay a ransom of 150 Shards, . If not, the brigands kill you.
book2.29.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="29">
	To travel on from here by river, you must pay a fare of 5 Shards.
	Otherwise you can cross the bridge and set out in the direction
	of the Singing Forest, or travel into the hinterlands.
	<choices>
		<choice book="5" section="111">Go west</choice>
		<choice section="327">Take the road to Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="350" shards="5">Travel upriver</choice>
		<choice section="121" shards="5">Travel downriver</choice>
		<choice section="52">Go north across open country</choice>
		<choice section="75">Go south across open country</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.290.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="290">
	The hydra spits acid at your back.
	<if armour="?" using="t">
		<tick special="armourlock" hidden="t"/>
		If you are wearing any 	armour, you have to strip it off and discard it before the acid eats through to your skin.
		<lose armour="?" using="t">Cross the armour off</lose>
		your Adventure Sheet.
	</if>
	<else>
		(If you didn’t have any armour, you
		<lose stamina="3d">lose 3-18 Stamina points</lose>
		instead.)
	</else>
	If you are still alive, <goto section="640"/>.
</section>
book2.291.xml: Castle Orlock is a brooding fortress encased behind walls of weathered black granite. The interior is unlit, and in order to explore you must have a lantern or candle. Enter the castle Go on your way
book2.292.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="292" tag="temple">
	‘You do not have to be an initiate to worship here,’ intones a
	priest, ‘but it makes the temple’s services that much cheaper.’
	<choices>
		<choice section="197">Become an initiate of Alvir and Valmir</choice>
		<choice section="243">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="2">Leave</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.293.xml:
You tell the high priest that you wish to renounce the worship of Nagil. He summons four acolytes bearing a pall and asks you to lie on it so that they can carry you outside. When you ask what that symbolizes, he gives a faint shrug and says, ‘You must draw your own conclusion.’

Do you want to reconsider? If you are determined to renounce your faith, delete Nagil from the God box on your Adventure Sheet. You must lose any outstanding resurrection arrangements, and also the title Chosen One of Nagil if you have it. When you have finished here, .
book2.294.xml:
Lacuna is the moon goddess and the overseer of the hunt. She is the patron deity of woodsmen, hunters and those who walk in the wild corners of the world.

Her temple here in Haggart’s Corner is a simple log-built chapel with bronze shields set along the walls. Grass carpets the floor and there is a smell of heather in the air. Pine cones smoulder on the altar.

Become an initiate of Lacuna Renounce her worship Seek a blessing Leave
book2.295.xml:
You don’t see what happens to the woman. She was right behind you as you approached the altar, but when you turn around she is nowhere to be seen.

Gain 1 point of SANCTITY for your generosity to the woman, then .
book2.296.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="296">
	The guards are convinced by your persuasive tongue. One of
	them gestures with his thumb, saying, ‘Go on in, then, before I
	change my mind.’ <goto section="342"/>.
</section>
book2.297.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="297">
	<lose codeword="2.297.1" hidden="t"/>
	The knight is no easy opponent. Perhaps you should flee while
	you still can.
	<flee>
		(If you do he will <lose stamina="1d">hit you for 1-6 Stamina points</lose> as you <tick codeword="2.297.1">run off</tick>.)
	</flee>
	<fight name="Silent Knight" combat="7" defence="12" stamina="7"/>
	<choices>
		<choice box="2.297.1" section="23">If you run away</choice>
		<choice section="320">If you win</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.298.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="298">
	Tendrils of magical force hold you rooted to the spot. The
	corpse’s bleak gaze burrows into your soul like a maggot into
	decaying flesh. To escape its clutches you must
	<difficulty ability="magic" level="15"/>.
	<outcomes>
		<success section="321"/>
		<failure section="275"/>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.299.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="299">
	The belfry contains nothing of interest. You decide to leave
	before the bats awaken and find you here. Hurrying back down
	the stairs, you return the way you came. <goto section="22"/>.
</section>
book2.3.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="3">
	The merchants’ guild in Wishport is too small to trade on behalf
	of its clients, but at least you can bank money here for safe
	keeping.
	<lose codeword="2.36.1" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.2" hidden="t"/>
	<tick codeword="2.36.3" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.4" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.5" hidden="t"/>
	<choices>
		<choice section="36">Make deposit or withdrawal</choice>
		<choice section="217">Return to the town centre</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.30.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="30">
	You are in the broad valley of the Rainbow River. Close to the
	riverbanks, fertile soil means that there are many villages. Up on
	the wooded valley slopes, you see only the occasional stonewalled
	croft. A pedlar tells you that the countryside hereabouts
	has an eerie reputation.
	<choices>
		<choice section="303">Stay close to the river</choice>
		<choice section="326">Venture further afield</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.300.xml:
An elf approaches out of the foliage surrounding you. He looks like a green candle-flame against the darkness. In his hands he bears a slim silver sword, which he presents to you with a solemn bow. ‘Now my debt to you is repaid,’ he murmurs before vanishing off into the depths of the wood.

You get a but must lose the codeword Bosky.

Follow the elf Continue searching the woods
book2.301.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="301" tag="temple">
	<if god="Alvir and Valmir">
		<tick codeword="2.301.1" hidden="t"/>
	</if>
	<else>
		<lose codeword="2.301.1" hidden="t"/>
	</else>
	The temple of Alvir and Valmir is a great pillared edifice of
	blazing white marble on the esplanade looking out over the bay.
	The twin gods are responsible for storms at sea. In the nave of
	the temple, a mural depicts them as fishers hauling up the souls
	of the drowned in their nets.
	<outcomes>
		<outcome codeword="2.301.1" section="269">If an initiate</outcome>
		<outcome section="292">If not an initiate</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.302.xml:
Wishport market is located in a warren of alleys adjacent to the waterfront. Each alley is dedicated to a different commodity. In one you can buy rope, in another lanterns, and so on. You hear the echo of hammer on anvil from the weaponsmith’s forge just ahead.

Items which have no purchase price listed are not available locally.

The market is where you can buy and sell possessions to carry on your person. To buy trade goods that can be carried on board ship, you need to visit the warehouses at the waterfront.

When you’re through here, .
book2.303.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="303" image="303.jpg">
	You come to a pool at the bottom of a waterfall. Here a fine
	spray hangs in the air like sparkling mist. The longer you look at
	it, the more you imagine you can see dancing figures outlined in
	the mist. Above the roar of the waterfall you seem to hear soft
	voices calling out to you.
	<choices>
		<choice section="692">Stay here a while longer</choice>
		<choice section="716">Leave now</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.304.xml:
The road is built of old grey cobblestones, which are now half overgrown with a carpet of rich green grass. Sometimes you pass a patrol of soldiers or a peasant leading his cattle to market. You do not expect any trouble on this well-patrolled stretch of road.

for encounters:

An eerie light in the dusk An uneventful journey A pardoner
book2.305.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="305">
	The Haunted Hills are virtually uninhabited, except for
	will-o’-the-wisps, monsters and a few mad outcasts.
	<random type="travel"/> to see what you encounter:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-4" section="760">A sulphurous cave</outcome>
		<outcome range="5-6" section="394">A prophet of doom</outcome>
		<outcome range="7" section="172">A trouble-free journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-9" section="419">Outlaws</outcome>
		<outcome range="10-12" section="444">A hungry ghost</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.306.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="306">
	The countryside between the River Grimm and the Whistling
	Heath is dotted with quaint villages where the tavern-talk is of
	elfin glades and the pranks of goblins at night.
	<random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-4" section="597">An unusual wager</outcome>
		<outcome range="5-7" section="621">A night at an inn</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-9" section="153">An uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="10-12" section="645">A chuckling in the woods</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.307.xml:
The ship weighs anchor and steers majestically out of Ringhorn harbour. ‘This’ll be a trouble-free haul,’ thinks the captain. ‘I can smell it on the wind.’

He is obviously a seasoned mariner. Fifteen days later you are putting into dock at Yellowport. On the way there has been no sign of pirate vessels and just a steady strong breeze to carry you on your way. If only every sea voyage could be so uneventful!

Turn to 140 in The War-Torn Kingdom.
book2.308.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="308">
	You approach the captain of a Sokaran brigantine which is soon
	to set sail. He is happy to make a little extra money by taking a
	paying passenger along. You soon discover that passage to
	Marlock City or Ringhorn will cost you 10 Shards, while
	passage to Yellowport costs 15 Shards. You can pay the fare and
	set sail at once, or give up and review your other options
	instead.
	<choices>
		<choice shards="15" section="239">Set sail for Yellowport</choice>
		<choice shards="10" section="262">Set sail for Marlock City</choice>
		<choice shards="10" section="163">Set sail for Ringhorn</choice>
		<choice section="33">Don’t put to sea</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.309.xml:
The road wends its way past countless numbers of farms, passing through villages where the peasants live well on their bountiful harvests.

for encounters:

A loathly lady An uneventful journey A minstrel
book2.31.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="31">
	You are on the road that skirts the Whistling Heath and
	continues down towards the coast.
	<choices>
		<choice section="193">Head south towards Metriciens</choice>
		<choice section="71">Go north to Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="98">Leave the road and go west</choice>
		<choice section="195">Leave the road to head east</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.310.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="310">
	You are on the road leading from the Monastery of Molhern to
	Wheatfields, the market capital of central Golnir.
	<choices>
		<choice section="94">Go south-east to the monastery</choice>
		<choice section="333">Head north-west to Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="195">Head south-west to the Whistling Heath</choice>
		<choice section="123">Head north-east to the Rainbow River</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.311.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="311">
	The tavern costs you 1 Shard a day.
	<rest stamina="1" shards="1">Each day you spend here</rest>,
	you can recover 1 Stamina point if injured, up to the limit of
	your normal unwounded Stamina score. When you are ready to
	leave, <goto section="2"/>.
</section>
book2.312.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="312">
	An old hogwarden tells you that the Abbey of Lacuna lies to the
	north. ‘It’s at the end of a winding road that only the faithful can
	ever find,’ he claims.
	<choices>
		<choice section="7">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="168">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="99">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="237">Go west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.313.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="313">
	Each time you slice through one of the hydra’s necks, it grows
	another head. You soon see that the only way to defeat it is to
	strike at the point where all necks join the body.
	<fightdamage type="add"><tick codeword="HydraDamage" hidden="t"/></fightdamage>
	<fight name="Hydra" combat="6" defence="11" stamina="9"/>
	If you kill it, <goto section="361"/>.
</section>
book2.314.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="314">
	You leave Castle Orlock behind. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-6" section="600">Pursued</outcome>
		<outcome range="7" section="268">Uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-9" section="337">A pitfall</outcome>
		<outcome range="10-12" section="360">Smugglers</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.315.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="315">
	Castle Ravayne is virtually a city in its own right: the outer
	courtyard is filled with stables, grain stores, pens for livestock,
	carpentry yards and a smithy. Nearby, some knights are keeping
	fighting fit by charging with lances at a straw-filled dummy.
	Beyond, another line of defences encloses the inner keep.
	<choices>
		<choice section="43">Visit the shrine to the war-god Tyrnai</choice>
		<choice section="66">Visit the armoury</choice>
		<choice section="89">Practice swordplay</choice>
		<choice section="624">Rob the treasury</choice>
		<choice section="112">Enter the inner keep</choice>
		<choice section="118">Leave the castle</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.316.xml:
Resurrection costs 200 Shards if you are an initiate, 600 Shards if not. (If you have the title Chosen One of Nagil it is free of charge.)

Resurrection is the last word in insurance. Once you have arranged for resurrection you need not fear death, as you will be magically restored to life here at the temple.

To arrange resurrection, pay the fee and write Temple of Nagil (Cities of Gold and Glory 339) in the Resurrection box on your Adventure Sheet. If you are later killed, turn to 339 in this book.

You can have only one resurrection arranged at a time. If you arrange another resurrection later at a different temple, the original one is cancelled. (Cross it off your Adventure Sheet. You do not get a refund.)

When you are finished here, .
book2.317.xml:
Becoming an initiate of Lacuna gives you the benefit of paying less for blessings and other services the temple can offer. It costs 30 Shards to become an initiate. You cannot do this if you are already an initiate of another temple.

If you choose to become an initiate, write Lacuna in the God box on your Adventure Sheet - and remember to cross off the 30 Shards. Once you have finished here, .
book2.318.xml:
The high priestess sweeps forward and divests you of the three talismans. ‘What a thoughtful gift!’ she trills. ‘The goddesses will be so pleased.’

Cross the , and rabbit’s foot charm off your Adventure Sheet. Later, you are strolling across the village green when a huge gold nugget whistles down out of the sky and thuds into the grass right in front of you.

‘That’s handy, Harry,’ remarks a nearby alewife to her husband.

You sell the nugget for . After recording the money on your Adventure Sheet, .
book2.319.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="319">
	You are given a sound drubbing for your impertinence.
	<lose stamina="2">Lose 2 Stamina points</lose> and (if still alive)
	<random dice="1"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="1-3" section="365">Thrown in the dungeon</outcome>
		<outcome range="4-5" section="118">Thrown in the moat</outcome>
		<outcome range="6" section="315">Let off with a warning</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.32.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="32">
	You are on the coastal road that snakes along the windswept
	clifftops between Ringhorn port and the market town of
	Metriciens. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-5" section="424">Attacked by highwaymen</outcome>
		<outcome range="6-7" section="55">An uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-12" section="449">You meet a militia patrol</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.320.xml:
Your opponent falls with a heavy clatter to the sward, releasing a wisp of green vapour. When you throw open the visor, you are amazed to see the armour is empty.

The dwarf comes running out of the pavilion in a state of high dudgeon. ‘You cheated!’ he says. ‘It isn’t fair. I will have my revenge.’ So saying, he darts off into the bushes.

Get the codeword Baluster . You can take the remnants of your uncanny opponent: and a . Also , and if the total is higher than your COMBAT score then increase it by 1.

Continue along the path Leave the forest
book2.321.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="321">
	Severing the spells that held you transfixed, you send forth a
	golden light that forces the vampire knight to recoil in pain.
	You lose no time in racing off, not stopping until you are out of
	the Forest of the Forsaken. <goto section="23"/>.
</section>
book2.322.xml: The more treasure you collect, the longer it will take and the greater the chance the bats will notice you. Decide how much you will collect [click here when you're done], then and add 1 to the total for every 100 Shards you have taken. You leave with your loot The vampire bats awaken
book2.322old.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="322">
	<lose codeword="RandomPlus" hidden="t"/>
	<tick codeword="2.322.1" hidden="t"/>
	The more treasure you collect, the longer it will take and the
	greater the chance the bats will notice you. Decide how much
	you will collect, then
	<group>
		<text>roll two dice</text>
		<random force="f">
			<adjust name="RandomPlus"/>
		</random>
		<lose codeword="2.322.1"/>
	</group>
	and
	<if codeword="2.322.1">
		<tick name="RandomPlus" count="1" price="x">add 1 to the total</tick>
		for every
		<tick shards="100" flag="x"/> you have taken.
	</if>
	<field name="RandomPlus" label="Add:"/>
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-10" section="345">You leave with your loot</outcome>
		<outcome range="11+" section="368">The vampire bats awaken</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.323.xml: The creature’s armour is too heavy to suit you, but you can take a , a boar’s tusk and that it had in its purse. Record your acquisitions and then .
book2.324.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="324" tag="temple">
	The temple of Elnir is a majestic palace of black marble inlaid
	with veins of gold. Elnir is the foremost god of the pantheon,
	the patron of warlords and kings. His realm is said to lie between
	the mountains and the sky, and whenever there is a storm the
	simple folk say, ‘Something has angered Elnir.’
	<choices>
		<choice section="63">Become an initiate of Elnir</choice>
		<choice section="86">Renounce his worship</choice>
		<choice section="109">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="2">Leave</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.325.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="325" dock="Wishport">
	The harbour of Wishport. Here you can buy a ship, or put to
	sea if you already have a ship docked at this location. It is also
	possible to visit the warehouses lining the waterfront, where
	goods from afar are bought and sold in quantity.
	<choices>
		<choice section="233">Buy a ship</choice>
		<choice section="256">Sell a ship</choice>
		<choice section="279" sail="t">Go aboard your ship</choice>
		<choice section="50">Hire crew for your ship</choice>
		<choice section="73">Pay for passage on a ship</choice>
		<choice section="96">Visit the warehouses</choice>
		<choice section="217">Go to the city centre</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.326.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="326">
	These are eerie woods haunted by the rustling of leaves and the
	occasional mournful cry of an animal far off between the trees.
	Not many people are to be seen this far from the farmlands of
	the river valley. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-4" section="620">Smoke over the treetops</outcome>
		<outcome range="5-6" section="644">A robber</outcome>
		<outcome range="7-8" section="349">Uneventful journey</outcome>
		<outcome range="9-12" section="668">A hole under an oak tree</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.327.xml:
You are travelling on an old stone road. Carved limestone monoliths occur at intervals of seven leagues, each with an inscription marking the distance to the High King’s Seat.

for encounters:

Pilgrims An uneventful journey A plague-ridden hag
book2.328.xml:
The Endless Plains are ‘the Breadbasket of Golnir’ - a vast rolling expanse of fields that gleam in summer like quilts of gold. Pretty whitewashed villages nestle beside lazy streams. The farms are filled with plump livestock. Danger is unknown to the inhabitants of this idyllic landscape.

When you are ready to head on towards fresh pastures, .
book2.329.xml:
The road snakes on between the verdant farmland. To either side you see peasants working in the fields. The barns and thatched-roofed cottages present an idyll of peace and contentment.

for encounters:

Seven fools An uneventful journey A mad thatcher
book2.33.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="33" dock="Metriciens">
	You are at the harbourfront in Metriciens. Here you can buy a
	ship - or put to sea, if you have ship docked at this location. It is
	also possible to visit the warehouses lining the waterfront, where
	goods from afar are bought and sold in quantity.
	<choices>
		<choice section="331">Buy a ship</choice>
		<choice section="10">Sell a ship</choice>
		<choice section="164" sail="t">Go aboard your ship</choice>
		<choice section="354">Hire crew for your ship</choice>
		<choice section="308">Pay for passage on a ship</choice>
		<choice section="285">Visit the warehouses</choice>
		<choice section="48">Go to the city centre</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.330.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="330" dock="Ringhorn" image="330.jpg">
	You search through the taverns along the waterfront, looking for
	seasoned sailors willing to crew your vessel. It costs
	<buy crew="average" shards="20"/> to upgrade a poor crew to average,
	<buy crew="good" shards="40"/> to upgrade average to good, and
	<buy crew="excellent" shards="80"/> to upgrade good to excellent.
	(These prices are cumulative, so the total cost of bringing a poor crew up to excellent is 140 Shards.) Once you’ve recorded any changes to your Ship’s Manifest, <goto section="255"/>.
</section>
book2.331.xml:
Owning a ship has two advantages. First, it makes it much easier to travel around. Second, it allows you to get rich by trading goods in bulk. Goods are transported in Cargo Units. (A Cargo Unit weighs several tonnes - much more than one person could carry!)

The more expensive your ship, the greater its carrying capacity. More expensive ships are also more seaworthy.

Choose a ship from the types listed here.

Record your ship in the Ship’s Manifest. You get to choose the ship’s name. The crew quality is average unless you hire on better sailors. Each time you arrive at a new destination, change the entry in the Docked column to the ship’s current location. (So if you aren’t going to sail straight away, note that the ship is docked at Metriciens.)

Hire on better crew Leave the city Visit the warehouses Return to the city centre
book2.332.xml:
A rugged track winds off through pasture land. A few rough looking types watch you askance as you pass them on the road.

for encounters:

Devout priests An uneventful journey Coarse ruffians
book2.333.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="333">
	A tavern squats beside a mill-pond. Weeping willows shade the
	tables in the beer garden at the back. It looks an inviting place to
	spend a few days.
	<choices>
		<choice section="12">Stop at the tavern</choice>
		<choice section="356">Press onwards</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.334.xml:
Becoming an initiate of Sig gives you the benefit of paying less for blessings and other services. Also, you can add 1 to your THIEVERY score, as Sig will watch over your pilfering activities and keep you safe from the law. It costs 50 Shards to become an initiate. (You cannot do this twice to obtain a double THIEVERY bonus!) You must not be an initiate of any other temple.

If you choose to become an initiate, write Sig in the God box on your Adventure Sheet - and remember to cross off the 50 Shards.

Once you have finished here, .
book2.335.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="335">
	You are sailing in waters close to Port Ringhorn.
	<choices>
		<choice book="5" section="26">Go west</choice>
		<choice book="3" section="200">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="106">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="255">Dock at Ringhorn</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.336.xml:
Your arrival at the Abbey of Lacuna is greeted by friendly waves from the nuns. Hastening into the main building, you kneel to the abbess and tell her of your recent adventures.

‘The goddess has guided you home to us,’ she says with a broad smile.

Seek a blessing Renounce initiate status Rest here for a while Leave at once
book2.337.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="337">
	Wily brigands have set a concealed trap out of the downs. To spot it in time to avoid getting caught, you need to
	<difficulty ability="scouting" level="12">
		make a SCOUTING roll at a Difficulty of 12
	</difficulty>.
	<outcomes>
		<success section="268"/>
		<failure section="289"/>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.338.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="338">
	The ground rises, becoming drier, and you realize you are
	leaving the Magwort Fens.
	<choices>
		<choice section="306">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="217">Go west to Wishport</choice>
		<choice section="130">Go east</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.339.xml:
You are restored to life at the Temple of Nagil in Metriciens. Your Stamina is back to its normal score. The possessions and cash you were carrying at the time of your death are lost - cross them off your Adventure Sheet. Also remember to delete the entry in the Resurrection box now it has been used.

‘Nagil be praised!’ intone the priests. ‘Nagil is the greatest of all the gods.’

Dazed by the experience of rebirth, you stumble outside for a breath of fresh air. .
book2.34.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="34">
	An eerie glimmer shines between the trees that overhang the
	road a little way ahead. Venturing a little further, you see in the
	gathering darkness that an old iron gibbet is set on one side of
	the road. The glowing light hangs around it like a bubble of
	marsh gas.
	<choices>
		<choice section="57">Go closer to investigate</choice>
		<choice section="11">Back off and wait till morning</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.340.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="340">
	To renounce the worship of Lacuna, you must pass an ordeal of
	judgment. This entails the high priestess shooting a silver arrow
	at you along the length of the nave. ‘If Lacuna bears you no ill
	will, the arrow will miss its target,’ you are assured.
	<choices>
		<choice section="378">Submit to the ordeal</choice>
		<choice section="294">Stay an initiate after all</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.341.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="341">
	As a member of the nobility, you are admitted to the castle
	without delay. Peasants’ carts are pushed aside by the sentries so
	that you can sweep majestically past. <goto section="315"/>.
</section>
book2.342.xml:
The inner keep of the castle is a mighty fortress with walls several metres thick. Narrow windows admit golden shafts of sunlight into the gloomy hallway.

If you have the title Paladin of Ravayne then you know these ancient halls well, and there is even a private chamber set aside for your use.

Visit your chamber (if a Paladin) Visit the chapel of the god Elnir Seek out the wizard Estragon Request an audience with the baroness Leave the keep
book2.343.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="343">
	The foliage around you is filled with eerie rustling noises. The
	boles of the trees are black and twisted with age. Before long
	you come to a fork in the path.
	<choices>
		<choice section="366">Go left</choice>
		<choice section="22">Go right</choice>
		<choice section="23">Go back</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.344.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="344">
	At the back of the knight’s crypt you find a
	<item name="green medallion"/>.
	When you are ready to leave, <goto section="22"/>.
</section>
book2.345.xml:
You hurry back down the stairs. Your courage deserves a greater reward than mere treasure. , and if the result is greater than your current Rank then you gain a Rank. You also gain 1-6 Stamina points permanently - that is, increase your normal (unwounded) Stamina score by the roll of one die. Remember that going up a Rank increases your Defence.

Once you have made any necessary adjustments to your Adventure Sheet, .
book2.346.xml: A severed head lies on top of a tree stump. Its eyes are open and, moving closer, you are given a nasty shock when it suddenly speaks: ‘I have a favour to ask. Would you take me to the hut of the hermit Knocklar? He’s always taking me out with him when he goes to cut wood and then leaving me behind.’ Having said its piece, the falls silent and closes its eyes. Add it to your list of possessions if you wish, then .
book2.347.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="347" tag="temple">
	The temple of Sig is a narrow high-gabled edifice close to the
	waterfront. Nominally Sig is the patron deity of lovers,
	vagabonds and travelling entertainers, but he is also god of
	cunning and deception, and as such is worshipped by those who
	live outside the law.
	<choices>
		<choice section="334">Become an initiate of Sig</choice>
		<choice section="375">Renounce the worship of Sig</choice>
		<choice section="13">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="2">Leave</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.348.xml:
You can leave possessions and money here to save having to carry them around with you. Record in the box anything you wish to leave. Each time you return, :

Your possessions are safe A thief; all the money you left here has gone A gang of burglars; lose all possessions you left here A fire; your town house and all its contents have been destroyed

You can also rest at your town house for as long as you wish. If injured, restore your Stamina to its normal unwounded score.

When you’ve finished at your town house, (and remember to erase the tick in the town house box there if it was destroyed by fire).
book2.349.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="349">
	You are journeying through sparsely inhabited country east of
	the Endless Plains. Northwards lie the Haunted Hills.
	Somewhere off to the south is the town of Goldfall, where it is
	said that nuggets of precious metal drop each night from the sky.
	<choices>
		<choice section="328">Head west</choice>
		<choice section="305">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="123">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="237">Go east</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.35.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="35">
	You are on the road leading south-east from the market town
	of Wheatfields towards the Monastery of Molhern.
	<choices>
		<choice section="333">Head for the monastery</choice>
		<choice section="71">Make for Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="195">Head south-west towards the Whistling Heath</choice>
		<choice section="328">Head north into the Endless Plains</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.350.xml:
The boat wends its way sluggishly upriver against the current. The rich fields gradually give way to grazing land and rugged heath. One evening at dusk you see a pallid green light flickering far off in the east, across the desolate countryside. The sailors tell you the light shines from the top of the Tower of Despair. ‘A haunted place where an ogre king once dwelt,’ adds the captain in a hushed voice.

The next day you arrive at Marmorek. This is as far as the boat is going. If you want to return south with them, you must pay another 5 Shards for your fare.

Stop off at Marmorek Sail back downriver
book2.351.xml:
You are traversing the Spine of Harkun mountain range. Distantly against the sky you can see the massive bulk of Sky Mountain. The forked snow-clad peak resembles a crone’s broken tooth. According to legend, the moon once caught on the peak and the Mannekyn People had to fly up to break it loose. No human has ever scaled Sky Mountain, as far as you know.

for events along the way:

A hydra Nothing of note Mannekyn People
book2.352.xml:
The road sweeps around through the meadows and fields of eastern Golnir. In places it is in dire need of repair. A peasant leaning on a turnstile tells you that a man once fell into one of the road’s flooded potholes during the rainy season. ‘’E wuz drowned!’

for encounters:

The High King’s messenger An uneventful journey The wizard Estragon
book2.353.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="353">
	You are on the coastal road. The great port city of Ringhorn lies
	not far to the west. The town of Metriciens is rather more
	distant to the east.
	<choices>
		<choice section="2">Head west</choice>
		<choice section="373">Head east</choice>
		<choice section="78">Leave the road and head north</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.354.xml:
You trawl through the taverns along the waterfront, looking for able seamen willing to crew your vessel. It costs to upgrade a poor crew to average, and to upgrade average to good. You cannot upgrade higher than that in Metriciens, because there aren’t enough good sailors.

Once you’ve recorded any changes in the ship box on the Ship’s Manifest, .
book2.355.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="355">
	You are on the ancient paved road between Delpton and Wheatfields.
	<choices>
		<choice section="6">Head west to Delpton</choice>
		<choice section="71">Head east to Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="52">Venture north over open country</choice>
		<choice section="75">Strike out due south</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.356.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="356">
	The sun is shining across the flower-filled meadows as you make
	your way on from Tekshin’s Tavern.
	<choices>
		<choice section="332">Take the road to Goldfall</choice>
		<choice section="309">Take the road to Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="352">Take the road to the Monastery of Molhern</choice>
		<choice section="195">Go cross-country towards the Whistling Heath</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.357.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="357">
	The merchants’ guild in Ringhorn . Here you can bank your
	money for safe-keeping - or invest it in guild enterprises in the
	hope of turning a profit.
	<tick codeword="Bastion">Acquire the codeword Bastion</tick>
	if you didn’t have it already.
	<tick codeword="2.36.1" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.2" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.3" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.4" hidden="t"/>
	<lose codeword="2.36.5" hidden="t"/>
	<choices>
		<choice section="39">Make an investment</choice>
		<choice section="62">Check on investments</choice>
		<choice section="36">Deposit or withdraw money</choice>
		<choice section="2">Return to the town centre</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.358.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="358">
	You are off the southern seaboard close to the wealthy
	mercantile city of Metriciens.
	<choices>
		<choice section="106">Go west</choice>
		<choice book="3" section="301">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="175">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="33">Dock at Metriciens</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.359.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="359">
	The broad, gently rolling pasturelands between the Grimm and
	the Rainbow rivers lie before you. Wool is sent south from here
	to make the rich gowns of the merchant princes of Ringhorn
	and Metriciens. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-6" section="15">Nuns from the Abbey of Lacuna</outcome>
		<outcome range="7-12" section="312">Uneventful journey</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.36.xml:
You can bank money with the merchants’ guild by writing the sum you wish to leave with the guild in the box here. (Remember to cross it off your Adventure Sheet.) If you have banked any money with the guild in another book in the Fabled Lands series, add it now to this box and erase it from the other book.

To withdraw money from your account, simply transfer it from the box to your Adventure Sheet. The guild charges 10% on any withdrawals. (So if you withdrew 50 Shards, for example, they would deduct 5 Shards as their cut. Round fractions in the guild’s favour.)

When you are ready to leave:

In Ringhorn In Metriciens In Wishport In Wheatfields In Conflass
book2.360.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="360" image="360.jpg">
	You see a group of smugglers bringing their contraband ashore
	by the light of the moon.
	<choices>
		<choice section="415">Show yourself</choice>
		<choice section="268">Continue on your way</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.361.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="361">
	The hydra’s bites were venomous.
	<if codeword="HydraDamage">
		<lose codeword="HydraDamage" hidden="t"/>
		If it managed to injure you at all during the battle, <goto section="377"/>.
	</if>
	<else>
		If not, <goto section="17"/>.
	</else>
</section>
book2.362.xml:
Becoming an initiate of Nagil is not possible if you are already an initiate of another temple. You are made to undergo various trials to test your worthiness. In the last test, you are sealed in a casket below the ground and made to confront your own fears.

To pass the test you must roll under your Rank on one die . If successful, write Nagil in the God box on your Adventure Sheet.

Once you have finished here, .
book2.363.xml:
If you are an initiate it costs only 10 Shards to purchase Lacuna’s blessing. A non-initiate must pay 25 Shards.

Cross off the money and mark in the Blessings box on your Adventure Sheet. The blessing works by allowing you to try again when you make a failed SCOUTING roll. It is good for only one reroll. When you use the blessing, cross it off your Adventure Sheet. You can have only one SCOUTING blessing at a time. Once it is used up, you can return to any branch of the temple of Lacuna to buy a new one.

When you are finished here, .
book2.364.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="364">
	Sentries with huge black halberds block your way across the
	heavy drawbridge. To convince them to let you enter, you must
	<difficulty ability="charisma" level="12">
		make a CHARISMA roll at a Difficulty of 12
	</difficulty>.
	<outcomes>
		<success section="315"/>
		<failure section="20"/>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.365.xml:
There is only one thing to be said for the dungeon of Castle Ravayne: there aren’t any rats. It’s far too uncomfortable for rats.

Lose all your possessions and cash . Also lose the title Paladin of Ravayne if you had it.

If you have the codeword Bashful, . If not .
book2.366.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="366">
	The path wends its way between steep earthern banks from
	which the roots of trees protrude like ossified snakes. It brings
	you to a squat crypt built of green-veined grey marble. Above
	the entrance rises a small pyramid with a stone eye carved into
	the summit. In the centre of the eye sparkles an emerald as large
	as a duck’s egg.
	<choices>
		<choice section="91">Climb up to get the emerald</choice>
		<choice section="160">Enter the crypt</choice>
		<choice section="22">Retrace your steps and take the other path</choice>
		<choice section="23">Leave the forest</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.367.xml:
The path leads to a clearing. In the middle stands a narrow windowless tower of jet black stone. Looking up, you see that the parapet of the tower is encrusted with small gems that glitter like stars. There is only a single door, banded solidly with panels of dark iron.

.
book2.368.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="368">
	Disturbed by the heavy chink of coins, a number of bats flutter	down from the rafters and sink their fangs into your flesh.
	<random dice="1" var="x"/>.
	You must
	<lose ability="stamina" amount="x">
		lose that many Stamina points permanently
	</lose>
	- i.e. reduce both your current and your normal (unwounded) Stamina score by this number. If you survive, you can shake off the bats and
	<goto section="345"/>.
</section>
book2.369.xml:
‘Knocklar, you oaf!’ says the severed head. ‘You dropped me in the forest again. If not for the kindness of this stranger I’d have lain there until morning with beetles crawling up my nostrils!’

Knocklar takes the head and smiles. ‘You must stay a while and tell me of your adventures,’ he says. ‘I have renounced the world myself in favour of a life of spiritual contemplation.’

‘A life of drunken idleness, more like!’ declares the head in outrage.

Knocklar leads you into his cottage where, ignoring the head’s protests, he stuffs it into a breadbin. Then he invites you to stay and have supper with him.

Cross the off your Adventure Sheet and then decide what you’re doing now.

Stay for supper Ask Knocklar for a blessing Gossip with him Leave the hermitage
book2.37.xml:
You are happy to share the fire on this cold night. As you sit on a pillow of dead leaves and watch the dancers, the heat of the fire makes you drowsy and your eyelids feel heavy because of the woodsmoke.

Make either a SANCTITY roll or a MAGIC roll (your choice) at a Difficulty of 15 .

Failed roll
book2.370.xml:
From Ringhorn, you have the option to put to sea, travel upriver, or journey overland. The fare to travel upriver is 5 Shards.

To travel by sea, you must either possess a ship which is docked in the harbour (check the Ship’s Manifest) or find a captain who is willing to take you as a passenger.

Go to the harbour Travel upriver (pay 5 Shards) Take the road north Take the coast road east Take the coast road west
book2.371.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="371">
	You are walking the riverbank beside the clear gurgling waters
	of the fast-flowing Rainbow River.
	<choices>
		<choice section="303">Head upstream</choice>
		<choice section="30">Head cross-country to the west</choice>
		<choice section="122">Head cross-country to the east</choice>
		<choice section="168">Head downstream to Conflass</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.372.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="372">
	This is wild, windswept heathland where shepherds eke out a
	meagre living.
	<choices>
		<choice section="305">Head towards the Haunted Hills</choice>
		<choice section="7">Head towards the Forest of the Forsaken</choice>
		<choice section="30">Follow the Rainbow River south</choice>
		<choice section="53">Go east towards the River Grimm</choice>
		<choice section="351">Go north up into the mountains</choice>
		<choice section="236">Strike out westwards</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.373.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="373">
	At the side of the coastal road there is a weathered old fort. It
	looks abandoned, with moss cladding the pitted black stones of
	its high walls. Its empty windows stare out to sea. It may be a
	relic from ancient times, when the ruthless Uttakin swept up out
	of the south to conquer all Harkuna.
	<choices>
		<choice section="9">Investigate the fort</choice>
		<choice section="78">Head north over open country</choice>
		<choice section="32">Take the road east</choice>
		<choice section="140">Take the road west</choice>
		<choice section="511">Go down to the beach</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.374.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="374">
	You are on an ancient cobbled road. Wheatfields is not too far
	to the north-east. Far off to the south-west lies Castle Ravayne.
	<choices>
		<choice section="71">Head towards Wheatfields</choice>
		<choice section="120">Head towards Castle Ravayne</choice>
		<choice section="75">Leave the road and go west</choice>
		<choice section="98">Leave the road and go east</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.375.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="375">
	<if god="Sig"><tick codeword="2.375.1" hidden="t"/></if>
	<else><lose codeword="2.375.1" hidden="t"/></else>
	To renounce the worship of Sig, you must pay 50 Shards in
	compensation to the priesthood. ‘You will also lose the good
	will of the deity,’ the high priest warns you darkly.
	<choices>
		<choice section="347">Stay an intiate after all</choice>
		<choice shards="50" box="2.375.1" section="59">Pay 50 Shards and renounce your faith</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.376.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="376">
	At last you locate a narrow winding path which leads to the
	Abbey of Lacuna. The moss-covered roofs of the abbey building
	loom above a hedgerow. As you approach the broad wooden
	lich-gate, you see nuns in their green-and-brown robes working
	in the gardens. <goto section="61"/>.
</section>
book2.377.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="377">
	You do not have long to celebrate your victory. The poison
	reaches your heart and you feel a stab of crippling pain. The
	only thing that can save you is a blessing of Immunity to
	Disease/Poison.
	<if blessing="poison">
		If you have such a blessing,
		<lose blessing="poison">cross it off</lose> and
		<goto section="17"/>.
	</if>
	<else>
		Otherwise you are dead within seconds - <goto section="560"/>.
	</else>
</section>
book2.378.xml:
You stand beside the door of the temple as the high priestess draws a bead on you with the sacred bow. The silver arrow glints menacingly in the afternoon sunlight. Then you hear the twang of the string as she shoots.

. If the total is higher than your Defence, the arrow finds its mark and you lose 1-6 Stamina points (roll a die to see how much). If the two dice score less than or equal to your Defence, the arrow misses.

Either way, if you survive then you are free to leave. Delete Lacuna from the God box on your Adventure Sheet and then .
book2.379.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="379" tag="temple">
	Elnir’s chapel is situated on an upper floor of the keep. As the
	guardian of rulership and law, he is the patron deity of the house
	of Ravayne.
	<choices>
		<choice section="67">Become an initiate of Elnir</choice>
		<choice section="90">Renounce his worship</choice>
		<choice section="113">Seek a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="342">Leave</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.38.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="38">
	The time has come for you to take your leave of the Abbey of Lacuna.
	<choices>
		<choice section="7">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="168">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="99">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="237">Go west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.380.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="380">
	You strike out from the path, forcing your way through the
	entangling undergrowth. Ferns sway off to one side, revealing a
	set of sparkling eyes in the gloom. Strange mutterings come
	from up in the branches. The eerie reputation of this forest is
	well deserved. <random type="travel"/>:
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="2-5" section="248">Elfin pranks</outcome>
		<outcome range="6-7" section="93">The denizens leave you alone</outcome>
		<outcome range="8-9" section="47">A voice calls out to you</outcome>
		<outcome range="10-12" section="70">Attacked by a wereboar</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.381.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="381">
	Knocklar has plenty of chores to get done. ‘I must chop some
	firewood, feed my chickens and go and check the traps out in
	the wood,’ he says. ‘So you’ll pardon me if I don’t stand around
	nattering with you all day.’
	<choices>
		<choice section="406">Ask him for a blessing</choice>
		<choice section="431">Request his advice</choice>
		<choice section="456">Bid him farewell</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.382.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="382">
	You reach a glade where a long table is laid out for a banquet. It
	is spread with silver plates piled high with succulent roast meat,
	spice cakes, warm fresh bread and large ripe fruits. Carved oak
	chairs are set out for thirteen guests.
	<choices>
		<choice section="407">Sit and eat your fill</choice>
		<choice section="432">Wait and watch</choice>
		<choice section="22">Retrace your steps</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.383.xml:
The seven fools are building a fence around a tree where a cuckoo is nesting. When you ask why, their explanation is that the song of the cuckoo tells them it is time to start sowing the crops. ‘If we keep the cuckoo penned up all year, we’ll be able to get in two or even three harvests, won’t we?’

Just as he says that, the cuckoo flies off.

The seven fools scratch their heads. ‘We’ll have to build it higher next year,’ says one.

‘Maybe we could get a grappling hook up on to a cloud...’ suggests another, but by this time you are sauntering away shaking your head. .
book2.384.xml:
Cross off all the money you are carrying. The brigands count it and give a sullen grunt. ‘Hardly worth collecting!’ says one, spitting into the dust at his feet.

‘I dunno,’ says the other. ‘After all, it’s free money, isn’t it?’

They dive into the woods bordering the road, leaving you to trudge on ruefully towards your destination. .
book2.385.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="385">
	You spend a restful night at the inn. If you are injured,
	<rest stamina="1">recover 1 Stamina point</rest>.
	The innkeeper asks you to
	<if shards="1"><lose shards="1">pay 1 Shard</lose></if>
	for the night’s lodging, but he is a charitable man and will not insist if you are broke. When you are ready to set out, <goto section="153"/>.
</section>
book2.386.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="386" image="386.jpg">
	The approaching vessel at first seemed to be an innocent
	merchantman, but then your lookout points to the banks of oars.
	‘A pirate galley!’ he cries. Sure enough, at that moment the ship
	hoists the red pennant of the Kingdom of the Reavers. Her oars
	give her a good burst of speed over short distances, and she is
	soon bearing down on you.
	<choices>
		<choice section="411">Make a run for it</choice>
		<choice section="436">Parley</choice>
		<choice section="461">Fight it out</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.387.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="387">
	<lose shards="*" item="*">
		Cross all money and possessions off
	</lose>
	your Adventure Sheet. You are lucky to have got away with your life. You hide inside a hollow tree until sunrise, but when you retrace your steps you cannot find the inn. <goto section="153"/>.
</section>
book2.388.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="388">
	You continue on your way after promising you will inform the
	damsel’s champion of her whereabouts.
	<tick codeword="Bridoon">Get the codeword Bridoon</tick> and
	<goto section="200"/>.
</section>
book2.389.xml:
Frightened by the power of your magic, the three wizards offer tribute if you will release them from the curse. to see what they offer you:

1 a

2 a

3

4 an

5 an

6 a

As you won the duel, you also get a chance to increase your MAGIC score. , and if the total exceeds your MAGIC score, increase your score by 1.

When you have finished here, .
book2.39.xml:
Lose the codewords Almanac, Brush and Eldritch if you have them.

You can invest money in multiples of 100 Shards. The guild will buy and sell commodities on your behalf using this money until you return to collect it. ‘Be advised that investments can go down in value as well as up,’ one of the guild traders reminds you.

Write the sum you are investing in the box here - or withdraw a sum invested previously. Once you’re done, .
book2.390.xml:
‘I have neither the time nor the patience to teach you any more of my secrets,’ says Estragon. ‘Musty libraries and dingy laboratories are not the best places to seek knowledge in any case. Go out into the world; look around you. Nature is the book in which all mysteries are revealed.’

He turns away, leaving you to find your own way back up to the castle.

.
book2.391.xml: If the box above is empty, put a tick in it now and . If the box is ticked and you have a dragon’s head, . If the box is ticked and you do not have a dragon’s head, .
book2.392.xml:
Sir Fontesque twirls his long moustache and demands the right of trial by combat. The next day you are obliged to meet him on the field in front of the keep. The truth of your accusation will be decided by the outcome of this duel, as ancient law dictates.

If you win, . If you surrender, .
book2.393.xml:
Delpton market is small by the standards of the great cities of the south coast, but you may find some useful knick-knacks. Items with no purchase price listed are not available locally.

When your business is finished here, .
book2.394.xml:
An insane old man dressed in a long grey robe comes stumbling up the path towards you waving a stout stick. His spittle-streaked beard and wild mane of hair remind you of the temple images of Nagil, the Lord of the Departed.

‘The world will soon end!’ he cries. ‘What will it profit you then to have the goodwill of the gods? They are doomed just as we are, fool!’

He touches you with his stick and barges past, disappearing around a bend in the trail. When you hurry to catch up, you find he has vanished.

Lose any blessings or resurrection arrangements you had , then .
book2.395.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="395">
	You find a tiny golden pebble worth <tick shards="2"/>. Although you
	return to town with a hangdog look, another prospector sees
	your find and is amazed. ‘It took me three weeks before I got
	my first sniff of gold!’ he says. ‘You’re a lucky devil, and no
	mistake.’
	<choices>
		<choice section="470">Try again tomorrow</choice>
		<choice section="104">Leave Goldfall</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.396.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="396">
	Some say that the whistling wind carries secrets from the
	afterlife. Is it that or some sixth sense that tells you something
	important is going to happen?
	<choices>
		<choice section="496">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="762">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="521">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="546">Go west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.397.xml:
You receive the blessing of Molhern. This allows you a second attempt to any one failed MAGIC roll. After the second roll (whether it is successful or not) the blessing is used up. Write: MAGIC reroll (one use) under the blessings on your Adventure Sheet.

You cannot obtain a second blessing from Molhern until this one is used up.

Now .
book2.398.xml:
The pedlar has a few bargains among the bric-a-brac on his cart:

After buying whatever you think might come in useful, .
book2.399.xml:
A heavy ship driven by churning paddles comes ploughing its way through the waves towards your ship. ‘A slave ship from Uttaku!’ gasps the captain. ‘Their vessel is powered by oxen, turning a shaft that moves those paddles. Tireless, but cumbersome and slow to manoeuvre. We might be able to outrun them.’

:

The slaver overhauls you You get away
book2.4.xml:
The temple of Alvir and Valmir is a white marble building with a wide portico which gives a panoramic view of the harbour. The air in the nave is cool and fresh after the blazing sunshine outside.

Alvir and Valmir, the twin gods, are responsible for storms at sea. Sailors believe they take the souls of the drowned down to their halls beneath the vasty deep.

Become an initiate Renounce worship of the twin gods Seek a blessing Leave the temple
book2.40.xml:
Something about the man makes you suspicious. Pretending to need to answer a call of nature, you watch from a bush while he goes through your belongings. You bide your time until he is occupied before stealing back everything he took off you, plus a few of his own possessions for good measure. He suspects nothing, and when it is time for you to go your separate ways he bids you farewell with a cheery wave.

Going through the items you filched off him, you find a , a rabbit’s foot charm and a . Note these on your Adventure Sheet and .
book2.400.xml:
Misshapen sprites with grotesque faces come scampering out of the hedge beside the road. Tittering to themselves, they prod you with gnarled fingers and discuss whether you are worth eating.

‘Give us an emerald and we’ll let you go,’ pipes up one of the sprites.

It seems they will accept a green gem to leave you in peace.

Give them a green gem Make a break for it
book2.401.xml:
‘We’ve been on a diplomatic mission to Baroness Ravayne,’ says the leader of the Sokaran group. ‘She’s promised sanctuary to our royal master if he should require it. Here, you must take this to him without delay.’

You are handed a . .
book2.402.xml:
A cloud of plague spores rises up the moment you lift the lid. Choking, you retreat to the open. The spores are germinating inside your lungs. Permanently reduce your Stamina by 1-6 (the roll of one die) unless you have a blessing of Immunity to Disease/Poison. If you did have a blessing, remember it is now used up.

After amending your Adventure Sheet, .
book2.403.xml:
As a hunter yourself, you doubt the cats have reformed quite that readily. Catching a mouse, you fling it in among them and the congregation dissolves into the usual feline squabbling and cruelty.

With an angry oath, the stranger vanishes in a puff of brimstone smoke, leaving behind a diamond worth . Note this as cash on your Adventure Sheet, then .
book2.404.xml: You take three swords , a and from the bodies before continuing on your way. .
book2.405.xml:
‘I have a special boon for such a devout worshipper,’ says the god. He touches you on the brow, leaving a silvery mark in the shape of a skull. Note on your Adventure Sheet that you have the title .

Swirling darkness surrounds you. ‘Do not fear,’ you hear Nagil saying. ‘You are being returned to the vale of mortality.’

.
book2.406.xml:
‘Bless you!’ he says, and indeed as he speaks those words you acquire the blessing of . Note this on your Adventure Sheet. It can be used once to negate the effect of disease or poison, and then you must cross it off.

‘You can get more blessings like that from the temple of Maka,’ says Knocklar. ‘Tell them I sent you and you might get a discount. Now, if you’ll excuse me...’

.
book2.407.xml:
Soon you are joined by a host of slender aristocratic figures in miniver robes. You hardly noticed their arrival, nor do you manage to get a clear look at their faces. Someone beside you says something witty and you find yourself laughing. It is like being in a dream.

To wake up you must make a MAGIC roll at a Difficulty of 12 .
book2.408.xml:
The militiamen - a troop of twenty soldiers and a sergeant - go tramping past with a jingling of chain mail. Their banner shows the black lion emblem of the House of Ravayne.

If you have a severed head, . If not, .
book2.409.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="409">
	A troop of militiamen comes marching along the road. A knight
	wearing the black lion of Ravayne on his tabard and shield rides
	at the head of the column.
	<if codeword="Bullion">
		If you have the codeword Bullion, <goto section="588"/>.
	</if>
	<else>
		If not, <goto section="353"/>.
	</else>
</section>
book2.41.xml:
Resurrection is free if you have the title Chosen One of Nagil. Otherwise it costs 200 Shards if you are an initiate, 600 Shards if not. It is the last word in insurance. Once you have arranged for resurrection you need not fear death, as you will be magically restored to life here at the temple.

To arrange resurrection, pay the fee and write Temple of Nagil (Cities of Gold and Glory 64) in the Resurrection box on your Adventure Sheet. If you are later killed, turn to 64 in this book. You can only have one resurrection arranged at any one time. If you arrange another resurrection later at a different temple, the original one is cancelled - cross it off your Adventure Sheet. (But you won’t get a refund!)

When you are finished here, .
book2.410.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="410">
	The approaching vessel at first appears to be an innocent
	merchantman, but then your lookout points to the banks of oars.
	‘A pirate galley!’ he cries. Sure enough, at that moment the ship
	hoists the red pennant of the Kingdom of the Reavers. Her oars
	give her a good burst of speed over short distances, and she is
	soon bearing down on you.
	<choices>
		<choice section="435">Make a run for it</choice>
		<choice section="460">Parley</choice>
		<choice section="485">Fight it out</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.411.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="411">
	<random dice="2">
		<adjust ability="rank"/>
		<adjust crew="poor" amount="-1"/>
		<adjust crew="good" amount="1"/>
		<adjust crew="excellent" amount="2"/>
	</random> and add your Rank. (Subtract 1 from the total if
	you have a poor crew. Add 1 if you have a good crew. Add 2 if
	you have an excellent crew.)
	<outcomes>
		<outcome range="1-6" section="461">The pirates overtake you</outcome>
		<outcome range="7+" section="14">You outrun them</outcome>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.412.xml:
The stranger leans closer, pressing his lips to your neck. You feel a pricking sensation. Jumping back, you see a trickle of blood on his sharp white teeth. A vampire!

Make a SANCTITY roll at a Difficulty of 12 .
book2.413.xml:
You break down the door of the tower and confront the evil knight who has imprisoned the damsel.

If you defeat him, you can set her free: get the codeword Brisket and .
book2.414.xml:
Your curse is deflected by their countercharms. The encounter ends in a draw. Your sailors stand at the rail and shake their fists at the wizards as they sail away. ‘Those hell-spawned devils!’ says the mate in a voice of strong emotion. ‘It’s getting so as it’s hardly safe to ply the regular shipping lanes.’

.
book2.415.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="415">
	The smugglers stop rolling their barrels of whisky up the beach and stare in amazement as you approach.
	<difficulty ability="charisma" level="12">
		Make a CHARISMA roll at a Difficulty of 12
	</difficulty>.
	<outcomes>
		<success section="539"/>
		<failure section="564"/>
	</outcomes>
</section>
book2.416.xml: If the box above is empty, put a tick in it now and . If the box is ticked and you have a map of the mountains, . If the box is ticked and you do not have a map of the mountains, .
book2.417.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="417">
	Sir Parpulax is of such obviously good character that everyone is
	prepared to vouch for him. He suggests that perhaps it is you
	who are the traitor.
	<if title="Paladin of Ravayne">
		If you have the title Paladin of Ravayne,
		<goto section="492"/>.
	</if>
	<else>If not, <goto section="319"/>.</else>
</section>
book2.418.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="418">
	The innkeeper charges 1 Shard a day. This entitles you to a mat
	beside the common-room fire and two hot meals.
	<rest stamina="1" shards="1">
		Each day you spend here
	</rest>, you can recover 1 Stamina point if injured, up to
	the limit of your normal unwounded Stamina score. When you
	are ready to leave, <goto section="443"/>.
</section>
book2.419.xml:
You are ambushed by a band of outlaws in wolf-pelt jerkins. They jump up from behind a ridge. You see at a glance that they far outnumber you, but they make no move to attack. Their leader signals for his men to lower their crossbows before scrambling down from the ridge to speak with you. ‘No offence,’ he says with a grin, ‘but one lone wanderer isn’t worth the trouble of robbing.’

Maybe he’d think differently if he could see inside your money-pouch? Or perhaps they are really put off because you look too tough to handle without casualties? See if you can impress them by making a THIEVERY roll and a CHARISMA roll , both at a Difficulty of 13.

Both rolls successful Fail one roll Fail both rolls
book2.42.xml:
Becoming an initiate of the Three Fortunes gives you the benefit of paying less for blessings and other services the temple can offer. It costs 90 Shards to become an initiate. You cannot do this if you are already an initiate of another temple. If you choose to become an initiate, write The Three Fortunes in the God box on your Adventure Sheet - and remember to cross off the 90 Shards.

Once you have finished here, .
book2.420.xml:
You have almost given up hope when you dig up a speck of gold worth .

‘What confounded luck!’ says a nearby prospector. ‘That means there’s a good chance of a large nugget buried there somewhere.’

You want to go on digging, but the daylight is going.

‘I’ll help you dig first thing tomorrow, if you like,’ says the prospector, as you walk back to town.

Try again tomorrow Leave Goldfall
book2.421.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="421">
	The wind thunders across the heath, rattling a small heap of
	pebbles stacked up by other travellers to mark the way.
	<choices>
		<choice section="496">Go north</choice>
		<choice section="521">Go south</choice>
		<choice section="762">Go east</choice>
		<choice section="546">Go west</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.422.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="422">
	Your prayer is heard by Molhern, who responds by telling you
	to travel to far lands in search of lost knowledge. You resolve to
	set out for the coast at once, there to take ship for foreign parts.
	<goto section="74"/>.
</section>
book2.423.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="423">
	You meet a youth who shamelessly confesses to all sorts of
	daring crimes. His stories give you some ideas of your own.
	<training ability="thievery" dice="1"/>,
	and if you score higher than your THIEVERY you
	can increase it by 1. Then <goto section="97"/>.
</section>
book2.424.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="424">
	Three highwaymen rise up from the side of the road. Two carry
	swords, the third has a crossbow aimed at your chest. Their faces
	are masked, but you can tell from the steely glint of their eyes
	that these are dangerous men.
	<choices>
		<choice section="746">Hand over your money</choice>
		<choice section="770">Fight</choice>
	</choices>
</section>
book2.425.xml:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<section name="425">
	You are sure someone is following you. Leading them around a
	mere, you lose them by ducking through a bank of fog. As you
	hurry away, you think you hear a snarl of frustrated rage. It
	makes you shudder - no human could have made that sound.
	<goto section="268"/>.
</section>
book2.426.xml:
They take you aside and speak in hushed tones, even though the one person within earshot is a drunken peasant. ‘Can’t be too careful,’ says one. ‘We’re on a top secret mission for General Marlock. Here, you’d better take him this.’

You are handed a . .
book2.427.xml:
To your horror, the casket contains a mouldered skeleton which comes to life as it feels the touch of fresh air. Grasping you by the throat, it drains some of your life force before vanishing with a peal of macabre laughter.

You stagger back to the open. You have lost one Rank. This reduces your normal (unwounded) Stamina score by 1-6 and will also reduce your Defence by 1. After amending your Adventure Sheet, .
book2.428.xml:
Scratching your head, you start to deliver your sermon, but the cats quickly get bored and wander off. ‘You don’t have the knack,’ says the stranger. ‘You have to keep people’s attention if you want to teach them the error of their ways.’ His tone is soothing, but he has a big triumphant grin on his face.

You have to give him all your possessions . (But not your money.) When you’ve done that, .
book2.429.xml: Your attempt to conjure an illusory dragon just produces a soft bang and a bad smell. Cackling with glee at your ineptitude, the witches cast an extraordinary hex on you. You now find that you are compelled to travel to the Haunted Hills without delay. You cannot stop at any towns or inns on the way. Once you reach the Haunted Hills, the compulsion will leave you and you can act normally. [I can't enforce this. Be as honest as you like --Ed] Now .
